docs.abstract: China reports new case of SARS in Guangdong Province one day after World Health Organization lifts ban on travel to Beijing and declares country to have effectively controlled disease; patient was already under quarantine as suspected SARS case (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: New Sars Case

docs.snippet: Just one day after the World Health Organization lifted its warning about travel to Beijing and declared that China had effectively won its battle against SARS, the country reported a fresh case of the disease. The case occurred in the southern provi
docs.lead_paragraph: Just one day after the World Health Organization lifted its warning about travel to Beijing and declared that China had effectively won its battle against SARS, the country reported a fresh case of the disease. The case occurred in the southern province of Guangdong, where SARS originated late last year. The Chinese authorities and W.H.O. officials minimized the significance of the latest case, arguing that it just confirmed a diagnosis of a patient who had already been isolated. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

docs.abstract: China appears set to select Japan's bullet train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between Beijing and Shanghai; estimated cost $12 billion (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: A High-Speed Rail

docs.snippet: China appeared set to select Japan's bullet train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said that the authorities had nearly settled on Japan
docs.lead_paragraph: China appeared set to select Japan's bullet train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail link between Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said that the authorities had nearly settled on Japan's shinkansen, or bullet train, for the 815-mile route, estimated to cost $12 billion. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

docs.abstract: Economic Observer, China's state news media, reports government is poised to purchase Japan's Shinkansen bullet train to link Beijing and Shanghai; high-speed rail technology will cost estimated $12 billion (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: China: Catching A Fast Train

docs.snippet: China appeared set to choose Japan's bullet-train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail service linking Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said authorities had nearly settled on Japan's Shi
docs.lead_paragraph: China appeared set to choose Japan's bullet-train technology for its new multibillion-dollar high-speed rail service linking Beijing and Shanghai, the state news media reported. The Economic Observer said authorities had nearly settled on Japan's Shinkansen, or bullet train, for the 815-mile route, estimated to cost $12 billion. Germany has been heavily promoting its high-tech magnetic levitation train, known as the Maglev. But Chinese officials have hinted recently that they favor traditional high-speed trains as more cost effective. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

docs.abstract: Hong Kong and China amend recent free-trade agreement that will make it easier for tourists from Beijing and Shanghai to visit Hong Kong; China will also support ongoing efforts by mainland companies to issue stock on Hong Kong Exchange and will consider letting Hong Kong banks take deposits, issue credit cards and conduct other retail transactions in renminbi, China's currency; China agrees to decide in September instead of December how much Hong Kong content will be required for goods to qualify for duty-free entry to China under pact (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Trade Concessions For Hong Kong

docs.snippet: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, announced that China had agreed to amend last month's free-trade agreement with Hong Kong to make it much easier for tourists from Beijing and Shanghai to visit Hong Kong, a former British colony that is no
docs.lead_paragraph: Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, announced that China had agreed to amend last month's free-trade agreement with Hong Kong to make it much easier for tourists from Beijing and Shanghai to visit Hong Kong, a former British colony that is now an autonomous Chinese territory but still has separate immigration and trade rules. Beijing will also support ongoing efforts by mainland companies to issue stock on the Hong Kong Exchange and will consider letting Hong Kong banks take deposits, issue credit cards and conduct other retail transactions in renminbi, China's currency. Beijing further agreed to decide in September instead of December how much Hong Kong content would be required for goods to qualify for duty-free entry to China under the pact. Mr. Tung sought a widening of the trade pact as part of a strategy of allaying public concerns in Hong Kong made evident by three large street protests earlier this month. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

docs.abstract: Photos from traveling exhibition by phototographer Zhou Hai showing factory workers and miners in today's China on view in Beijing, China (M)

headline.main: Capturing A Grimy Side Of China's Miracle

docs.snippet: Photos from traveling exhibition by phototographer Zhou Hai showing factory workers and miners in today's China on view in Beijing, China (M)

docs.abstract: Chinese Vice Foreign Minister Wang Yi visits North Korea to exchange views in advance of next month's six-party meeting scheduled in Beijing; China is seeking to renegotiate mutual defense treaty (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Chinese Envoy Arrives

docs.snippet: With six-party talks over North Korea's nuclear program expected to take place within a month in Beijing, China's vice foreign minister, Wang Yi, arrived in North Korea to exchange views on the talks and on bilateral ties. Earlier this year, China's
docs.lead_paragraph: With six-party talks over North Korea's nuclear program expected to take place within a month in Beijing, China's vice foreign minister, Wang Yi, arrived in North Korea to exchange views on the talks and on bilateral ties. Earlier this year, China's new leadership asked North Korea to renegotiate their mutual defense treaty, but North Korea refused until world pressure eases over the nuclear program. Next week, a higher-level Chinese delegation, led by Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing, is to visit South Korea. James Brooke (NYT)

docs.abstract: At least 36 people in Qiqihar, China, have taken ill after unearthing mustard gas Chinese officials say was left behind by Japanese troops at end of World War II, straining Japanese-Chinese ties; visit by Japanese Foreign Ministry team to probe accident overshadows separate Japanese delegation sent to mark 25th anniversary of normalization of ties; bitter history is also complicating China's choice of Japanese or European technology for high-speed rail link between Shanghai and Beijing; tens of thousands of Chinese have signed Web-based petitions calling on government not to award $12 billion contract to Japan; leaders from both countries publicly try to play down divisions; map; photo (M)

headline.main: Relic of War Adds to Strain In Beijing Ties With Tokyo

docs.snippet: China and Japan are supposed to be celebrating the 25th anniversary of the normalization of their relations this week, but they are instead entangled in fresh tensions over their ugly past.    At least 36 people in northeastern China have taken ill a
docs.lead_paragraph: China and Japan are supposed to be celebrating the 25th anniversary of the normalization of their relations this week, but they are instead entangled in fresh tensions over their ugly past. At least 36 people in northeastern China have taken ill after unearthing mustard gas that Chinese officials say was left behind by Japanese troops at the end of World War II.

docs.abstract: China's Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing, on visit to Japan, reports likelihood of six-party talks being held in Beijing aimed at ending North Korea's nuclear threat; it is speculated that China, Japan, Russia, South Korea, North Korea and United States will participate in meeting (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Talks Likely This Month

docs.snippet: Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing of China confirmed that six-party talks about how to end North Korea's nuclear program are to take place this month. Mr. Li, visiting Japan, said there was ''some foundation'' to reports that North Korea and the United St
docs.lead_paragraph: Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing of China confirmed that six-party talks about how to end North Korea's nuclear program are to take place this month. Mr. Li, visiting Japan, said there was ''some foundation'' to reports that North Korea and the United States, along with China, Japan, South Korea and Russia, would hold talks in Beijing beginning Aug. 26, though he declined to provide more detail. China diplomats have been engaged in shuttle diplomacy around the region to nail down the format and the timing of the negotiations. Joseph Kahn (NYT)

docs.abstract: BYD Co of Shenzhen says profit rose 27 percent to 325 million yuan ($39 million) in first half of year as sales rose 57 percent to 1.49 billion yuan ($180 million); plans to build factory in Beijing to help it meet increasing demand for its rechargeable lithium-ion batteries; graph (S)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit In Batteries

docs.snippet: A leading maker of rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, the BYD Company of Shenzhen, said its profit rose 27 percent to 325 million yuan ($39 million) in the first half as salesrose 57 percent to 1.49 billion yuan ($180 million). The company said it p
docs.lead_paragraph: A leading maker of rechargeable lithium-ion batteries, the BYD Company of Shenzhen, said its profit rose 27 percent to 325 million yuan ($39 million) in the first half as salesrose 57 percent to 1.49 billion yuan ($180 million). The company said it planned to build a factory in Beijing to help it meet increasing demand for its batteries used in products like cellphones and power tools.

docs.abstract: Two months after Chinese government declared that SARS is under control, merchants and small businesses dependent on China's annual influx of summer students are still reeling from repercussions; estimated 1,000 students from United States enroll in dozens of language programs each summer in Beijing, Shanghai and other cities; programs were canceled when SARS panic peaked in Apr and May (M)

headline.main: SARS Keeps Foreign Students Home, Hurting Chinese Businesses

docs.snippet: Most summers, Zhou Li does a brisk business selling soda and instant noodles to the enthusiastic foreigners studying Chinese next door. She sleeps on a bench in her convenience store, in case a student craves ice cream at 3 a.m.    But this summer, t
docs.lead_paragraph: Most summers, Zhou Li does a brisk business selling soda and instant noodles to the enthusiastic foreigners studying Chinese next door. She sleeps on a bench in her convenience store, in case a student craves ice cream at 3 a.m. But this summer, there are no students at the Beijing Language Institute. The program was canceled months ago because of SARS. Nor are there any students at the programs in China organized by Princeton, Johns Hopkins or dozens of others. They were canceled, too, because of SARS.
